content: Brian Ssali is an analyst at Livinggoods Uganda. His interests include data science and machine learning.
summary: Brian Ssali is an analyst at Livinggoods Uganda. His interests include data science and machine learning.
title: Brian Ssali

content:
We are going to look a dataset from the Tidytuesday on the passwords. The dataset entails the actual text of the password,the category of the password,time taken to crack the password(both online and offline) and the strength of the password.
Exploring the datasetWe use the skimr package to have a quick overview of the data with all the data types.
library(skimr)skimr::skim(passwords)(#tab:overview_of_dataset )Data summaryNamepasswordsNumber of rows507Number of columns9_______________________Column type frequency:character3numeric6________________________Group variablesNoneVariable type: character
skim_variablen_missingcomplete_rateminmaxemptyn_uniquewhitespacepassword70.994905000category70.994190100time_unit70.9947070Variable type: numeric
skim_variablen_missingcomplete_ratemeansdp0p25p50p75p100histrank70.99250.50144.481.00125.75250.50375.25500.00▇▇▇▇▇value70.995.608.441.293.433.723.7292.27▇▁▁▁▁offline_crack_sec70.990.502.660.000.000.000.0829.27▇▁▁▁▁rank_alt70.99251.22145.051.00125.75251.50376.25502.00▇▇▇▇▇strength70.997.435.420.006.007.008.0048.00▇▁▁▁▁font_size70.9910.303.650.0010.0011.0011.0028.00▁▇▁▁▁There are some rows with NAs that we are going to remove.It would be interesting to see the how long the passwords take to be cracked based on their corresponding categories and their strength as well
plot1 <- passwords %>%filter(!is.na(category)) %>%mutate(time_unit = factor(time_unit, levels = c("seconds", "minutes", "hours", "days", "weeks", "months", "years"))) %>%ggplot(aes(category, value, fill = time_unit)) +geom_point(aes(colour = time_unit), size = 2.5) + # coord_polar()# geom_jitter(aes(colour = time_unit))+coord_polar(clip = "on") +theme_dark() +theme(legend.position = "bottom", axis.text = element_text(colour = "black"), panel.grid.major = element_line("gray")) +scale_colour_manual(values = c("#FFDB6D", "#C4961A", "#F4EDCA", "#D16103", "#00AFBB", "#4E84C4", "#FC4E07"), guide = guide_legend(nrow = 1))plot1passwords %>%filter(!is.na(category)) %>%group_by(category) %>%transmute(strength = mean(strength, na.rm = T)) %>%tidyr::pivot_longer(cols = c(strength)) %>%arrange(value) %>%distinct(.) %>%ggplot(aes(value, reorder(category, value), fill = name)) +geom_segment(aes(xend = 0, yend = category)) +geom_point(size = 4, aes(color = category), show.legend = F) +geom_text(aes(label = round(value, 1)), hjust = -.5) +theme_minimal() +labs(x = "Strenght of Password", y = "Category of Password")
summary: We are going to look a dataset from the Tidytuesday on the passwords. The dataset entails the actual text of the password,the category of the password,time taken to crack the password(both online and offline) and the strength of the password.
title: #Tidytuesday Cracking Passwords

content:
This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are:
 You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc.  There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown. For example, you can write a task list with Blackfriday but not with Pandoc:
 Write an R package. Write a book. … Profit!  Similarly, Blackfriday does not support LaTeX math and Pandoc does. I have added the MathJax support to this theme (hugo-lithium) but there is a caveat for plain Markdown posts: you have to include math expressions in a pair of backticks (inline: `$ $`; display style: `$$ $$`), e.g., $S_n = \sum_{i=1}^n X_i$.^[This is because we have to protect the math expressions from being interpreted as Markdown. You may not need the backticks if your math expression does not contain any special Markdown syntax such as underscores or asterisks, but it is always a safer choice to use backticks. When you happen to have a pair of literal dollar signs inside the same element, you can escape one dollar sign, e.g., \$50 and $100 renders “$50 and $100”.] For R Markdown posts, you do not need the backticks, because Pandoc can identify and process math expressions.
When creating a new post, you have to decide whether the post format is Markdown or R Markdown, and this can be done via the ext argument of the function blogdown::new_post(), e.g.
blogdown::new_post("Post Title", ext = '.Rmd')
summary:
This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are:
 You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc.
title: A Plain Markdown Post

summary: R MarkdownThis is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.
title: Hello R Markdown
